verse_commentaries.commentary: The superscription תְּהִלָּה (tehillah) is rare - only here and Ps 145 uses this form instead of typical מִזְמוֹר. The combination 'my God and king' (אֱלוֹהַי הַמֶּלֶךְ) is unusual - personal possession of divine royalty. The verb אֲרוֹמִמְךָ (exalt) with 1st person imperfect suggests ongoing commitment.
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Establishes personal-royal tension that drives the psalm's movement to universality
verse_commentaries.phonetic_transcription: təhilāh lədhāwidh 'arwōmimkhā 'elwōhay hamelekh wa'avārəkhāh shimkhā ləʿwōlām wāʿedh

verse_commentaries.commentary: בְּכׇל־יוֹם creates daily temporal frame contrasting with eternal 'forever and ever'. Double verb pattern (bless/praise) with same divine name creates emphatic repetition. The phrase structure mirrors v.1 exactly - liturgical formulaic pattern.
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Temporal layering supports thesis about comprehensive scope

verse_commentaries.commentary: Shift from personal 'my God' to formal יְהֹוָה marks theological transition. The phrase אֵין חֵקֶר (cannot be fathomed) is rare - only here and Job 5:9, 9:10, 36:26. מְהֻלָּל (acclaimed) is passive participle suggesting universal recognition.
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Transcendence theme supports thesis about bridging cosmic/personal
verse_commentaries.phonetic_transcription: gādhwōl yəhōwāh wumhulāl mə'ōdh wəlighdhulāthwō 'ēyn khēqer

verse_commentaries.commentary: דּוֹר לְדוֹר (generation to generation) creates intergenerational chain. מַעֲשֶׂיךָ (works) vs גְּבוּרֹתֶיךָ (mighty acts) - two different categories of divine activity. Voice shifts from singular 'I will' to plural 'they will declare'.
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Supports thesis about expanding circles from personal to communal
verse_commentaries.phonetic_transcription: duwōr lədhwōr yəshabakh maʿaseykhā wughvwurōtheykhā yagiydhwu

verse_commentaries.commentary: הֲדַר כְּב֣וֹד הוֹדֶךָ - triple accumulation of glory terms is excessive even for Hebrew poetry. אָשִֽׂיחָה (I will recite/meditate) returns to personal voice after plural in v.4. נִפְלְאֹתֶיךָ (wondrous acts) adds third category of divine works.
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Glory accumulation supports thesis about divine transcendence

verse_commentaries.commentary: Qere/Ketiv issue: וגדלותיך/וּגְדֻלָּתְךָ shows textual uncertainty. נֽוֹרְאֹתֶיךָ (awesome deeds) - fourth category of divine works. עֱז֣וּז (might/power) is rare form, possibly intensive.
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Works proliferation supports thesis about comprehensive divine activity

verse_commentaries.commentary: זֵכֶר רַב־טוּבְךָ - 'memory/remembrance of abundant goodness' - interesting cognitive/temporal concept. יַבִּיעוּ (they shall pour forth/bubble up) suggests effusive, uncontrolled expression. צִדְקָתְךָ יְרַנֵּֽנוּ - righteousness causing singing.
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Effusive praise supports thesis about expanding response

verse_commentaries.commentary: Classic mercy formula from Exod 34:6 - חַנּוּן וְרַחוּם...אֶרֶךְ אַפַּיִם וּגְדׇל־חָסֶד. This is theological center, divine character revelation. Note גְדׇל־חָסֶד (great in kindness) vs usual רַב־חֶסֶד.
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Creedal center supports thesis about character as bridge between transcendence/immanence

verse_commentaries.commentary: טוֹב־יְהֹוָה לַכֹּל - universal goodness statement. רַחֲמָיו עַל־כׇּל־מַעֲשָׂיו - mercy extends to 'all his works' (creation). This is theological breakthrough - mercy beyond Israel.
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Universal mercy supports thesis about movement toward cosmic scope

verse_commentaries.commentary: יוֹד֣וּךָ...כׇּל־מַעֲשֶׂיךָ - all creation will praise (anthropomorphic). וַחֲסִידֶיךָ יְבָרְכֽוּכָה - faithful ones get special mention. Two different praise verbs: יוֹדוּ (thank/praise) vs יְבָרְכוּ (bless).
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Creation praise supports thesis about universal participation

verse_commentaries.commentary: מַלְכוּתְךָ focus - kingship theme emerges. כְּב֣וֹד מַלְכוּתְךָ vs גְבוּרָתְךָ - royal glory vs divine might. יֹאמֵרוּ...יְדַבֵּרוּ - speech verbs for royal proclamation.
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Kingship theme supports thesis about divine sovereignty as psalm center

verse_commentaries.commentary: לְהוֹדִיעַ לִבְנֵי הָאָדָם - infinitive of purpose, making known to humanity. גְּבוּרֹתָיו וּכְב֗וֹד הֲדַ֣ר מַלְכוּתֽוֹ - mighty acts plus royal glory compound. Note shift to 3rd person about God.
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Human focus supports thesis about bridging cosmic/personal
verse_commentaries.phonetic_transcription: ləhwōdhiyʿa  livnēy hā'ādhām gəvwurōthāyw wukhvwōdh hadhar malkhwuthwō

verse_commentaries.commentary: The Ugaritic parallel! מַלְכ֥וּת כׇּל־עֹלָמִ֑ים - eternal kingship formula. דּ֥וֹר וָדֹֽר returns from v.4. This verse is structural and theological center. Note the intensive repetition: מַֽלְכוּתְךָ֗ מַלְכ֥וּת.
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Central to thesis - this is the theological fulcrum between transcendence and immanence
verse_commentaries.phonetic_transcription: malkhwuthkhā malkhwuth kul-ʿōlāmiym wumemshaltkhā bəkhl-duwōr wādhōr

verse_commentaries.commentary: Missing nun verse in Hebrew! Sudden shift to concrete divine action. סוֹמֵךְ (supports) and זוֹקֵף (raises up) - physical helping verbs. הַנֹּפְלִים vs הַכְּפוּפִים - fallen vs bent down, different conditions.
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Missing nun creates structural gap at transcendence-immanence transition per thesis

verse_commentaries.commentary: עֵֽינֵי־כֹ֭ל אֵלֶ֣יךָ יְשַׂבֵּ֑רוּ - all eyes look expectantly. Anthropomorphic image of creation as dependent. בְּעִתּֽוֹ - 'in its time,' temporal precision of divine provision.
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Universal dependence supports thesis about divine accessibility

verse_commentaries.commentary: פּוֹתֵחַ אֶת־יָדֶךָ - opening hand, generous gesture. וּמַשְׂבִּיעַ לְכׇל־חַי רָצֽוֹן - satisfying every living thing's desire. רָצוֹן (desire/will) - not just need but want.
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Divine generosity supports thesis about immanent care

verse_commentaries.commentary: צַדִּיק יְהֹוָה בְּכׇל־דְּרָכָיו - righteous in all ways. וְחָסִיד בְּכׇל־מַעֲשָֽׂיו - faithful in all works. Note חָסִיד applied to God (usually of humans). Universal scope continues with כֹּל.
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Divine consistency supports thesis about reliable divine character

verse_commentaries.commentary: קָר֣וֹב יְהֹוָה לְכׇל־קֹרְאָיו - near to all who call. Divine accessibility despite transcendence. בֶאֱמֶֽת - 'in truth/sincerity,' condition for nearness. Repetition: קֹרְאָיו...יִקְרָאֻהוּ.
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Central to thesis about bridging transcendence and accessibility
verse_commentaries.phonetic_transcription: qārwōv yəhōwāh ləkhl-qōrə'āyw ləkhōl 'asher yiqrā'uhwu ve'emeth

verse_commentaries.commentary: רְצוֹן־יְרֵאָיו יַעֲשֶׂה - fulfills wishes of those who fear him. יְרֵאָיו (those who fear) - specific group. שַׁוְעָתָם יִשְׁמַע וְיוֹשִׁיעֵם - hears cry and saves, classic salvation pattern.
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Conditional divine care creates tension with universal themes

verse_commentaries.commentary: שׁוֹמֵ֣ר יְהֹוָה אֶת־כׇּל־אֹהֲבָ֑יו - watches over all who love him. Contrast: preserves lovers, destroys wicked. יַשְׁמִיד - strong destruction verb. Sharp ethical dualism emerges.
figurative_analysis: divine justice as guardian and destroyer
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Creates tension with universal themes - complicates thesis

verse_commentaries.commentary: תְּהִלַּ֥ת יְהֹוָ֗ה יְֽדַבֶּר־פִּ֥י - returns to personal voice 'my mouth.' וִיבָרֵ֣ךְ כׇּל־בָּשָׂר שֵׁ֥ם קׇדְשׁוֹ - 'all flesh' bless his holy name. Universal conclusion with 'forever and ever' inclusio.
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Perfect synthesis supporting thesis about personal-to-universal movement
verse_commentaries.phonetic_transcription: təhilath yəhōwāh yədhaber-piy wiyvārēkhə kul-bāsār shēm qdhəshwō ləʿwōlām wāʿedh f

thematic_threads: Missing nun verse creates deliberate structural gap at transcendence-immanence transition
Divine name progression: 'my God and king' → 'LORD' → 'the LORD' tracks personal to universal movement
Works categories multiply: works, mighty acts, wondrous deeds, awesome deeds - divine activity proliferation
Universal 'all' (כֹּל) intensifies through psalm: 9 times in final section emphasizing cosmic scope
Voice oscillation between personal singular and communal plural models expanding participation
Temporal layering: daily/generational/eternal timeframes create comprehensive temporal scope
Sharp tension between universal mercy (v.9) and ethical dualism (v.20) - theological puzzle
interesting_questions: Why does the psalm use the rare תְּהִלָּה superscription instead of the typical מִזְמוֹר?
What is the theological significance of the missing nun verse occurring precisely at the transition from cosmic kingship to personal care?
How do we reconcile the universal mercy 'to all his works' (v.9) with the destruction of the wicked (v.20)?
Why does the psalm multiply categories of divine works (מַעֲשִׂים, גְּבוּרוֹת, נִפְלְאוֹת, נוֹרְאוֹת) - do these represent distinct theological concepts?
What is the function of the Ugaritic royal formula in v.13 as both structural and theological center?
How does the voice progression from personal 'I will' to plural 'they shall' to universal 'all flesh' model the expansion of praise?
Why is חָסִיד (faithful) applied to God in v.17 when it typically describes human devotion?
What does the phrase הֲדַר כְּבוֹד הוֹדֶךָ accomplish with its triple accumulation of glory terms?
How does the 'all flesh' (כׇּל־בָּשָׂר) conclusion relate to the creation themes and anthropomorphic imagery throughout?
What is the relationship between God's 'unfathomable' greatness (v.3) and His 'nearness' to all who call (v.18)?
synthesis_notes:
LEXICON: Focus on תְּהִלָּה vs מִזְמוֹר, divine works vocabulary (מַעֲשִׂים/גְּבוּרוֹת/נִפְלְאוֹת), חָסִיד applied to God
CONCORDANCE: Track missing nun in acrostic psalms, 'all flesh' usage, Exodus 34:6 mercy formula variations
TEXTUAL: Examine LXX addition in v.13a, Qere/Ketiv in v.6, acrostic reconstruction theories
COMPARATIVE: Ugaritic royal formulas, ancient Near Eastern kingship vocabulary, creation anthropomorphism parallels
STRUCTURAL: Acrostic psalm patterns, voice progression in Hebrew poetry, inclusio techniques
